results.title: Your career: insurance
results.brief_description: Deals with the careers available to young men and women in the field of fire, accident and marine insurance. From correspondence sorting and office work, men can advance to executive positions, insurance inspectors, surveyors, and assessors. Women have the opportunity of careers as typists, punch card accounting machine operators and secretaries. Includes interesting shots of Melbourne and office procedures and equipment of the period (pre 1970s feminism).

results.title: Your brother, my tidda
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Kelrick Martin and Kathy Sport
results.brief_description:
“Coming out” to family, living with HIV and religion - some of the life changing situations faced by two Aboriginal gay men, Sam Barsah and Aaron Clark.
Sam has “come out” twice; first to his family about his sexuality and then about his HIV status. Like other indigenous gay men, he wants respect and understanding and only now, almost ten years later, does he feel able to speak openly about his story. Aaron is young and relatively new to Sydney. Growing up as a Jehovah’s Witness, he is looking for an alternative gay Christian group.
Using a contemporary blend of semi-observational filming, photos and animation, this short documentary about race and sexuality describes two very different stories of being Aboriginal and gay.
N.B. “Tidda” is an Aboriginal word for “sister”.

results.title: Your body and its parts
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and David Bennett
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Life Science”.
Provides an overview of human physiology. Illustrates the body parts working together to do a job and forming a system. Introduces the muscular, respiratory, circulatory, skeletal and nervous systems.

results.title: Your body : digestive system
results.brief_description: The digestive system is responsible for breaking down food and absorbing it into the body to provide energy to fuel all of the body’s functions and processes. This video provides a clear explanation of the following organs and functions of the digestive system: salivary glands, tongue, oesophagus, stomach, small and large intestine, liver, pancreas and peristalsis, the muscular contractions which move food through the entire digestive tract. Also explained are the stages involved in the body’s breakdown of food - from ingestion to elimination. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.

results.title: Your biological guide to AIDS (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: BBC, Vic Lockwood, Alison Tucker and Caroline Godley
results.brief_description: An informative question and answer format about AIDS presented by Mike Smith and Vicki Licorish. Discusses how the virus is transmitted; what it does to the body; how it affects your partner; the immune system; HIV; condom practice and protection. Includes interviews with AIDS sufferers.

results.title: Your biological guide to AIDS
results.creator_credit: BBC, Katherine Everett and Stuart McDonald
results.brief_description: Presenters from the Bodymatters Team separate facts from fiction and reveal how much the worldwide experts know about AIDS and its transmission. They explore the challenges ahead and the possibilities of finding a vaccine and a cure. The program dispels some of the myths surrounding the disease and uses giant models of the body to explain the action of the AIDS virus on other healthy cells.

results.title: Your amazing mind
results.creator_credit: Alfred Higgins Productions and Alfred Higgins
results.brief_description: Opens with a lengthy discussion of the importance of human brain power in the progress of civilisation. Proceeds to discuss the different types of drugs available and the dangers of using them without prescription. Explains various types of drugs and discusses the effects of each on the human brain.

results.title: Young Winston
results.creator_credit: Open Road Films, Columbia Pictures, Carl Foreman and Richard Attenborough
results.brief_description: This historical drama about British leader Winston Churchill, one of the 20th century’s great public figures, is based on his autobiography “My Early Life”. It chronicles his tumultuous rise to power from childhood to the age of twenty-six, when he delivered his first speech in the House of Commons covering his time as a war correspondent in India, his involvement in Kitchener’s Sudan expedition, and his capture and escape during the Boer War in South Africa. While it glosses over some of the less savory aspects of Churchill’s character, it nevertheless reveals him as a complex and very private man. The cast includes many esteemed British actors such as Robert Shaw, Ian Holm, Simon Ward, Anthony Hopkins, Edward Woodward and John Mills. Churchill’s mother was played by Anne Bancroft.

results.title: Young voices of Maffra = Future leaders : Young voices of Maffra
results.brief_description:
This film focuses on the young people of Maffra. Eight students from Maffra Secondary College were interviewed, representing all the year levels, and asked to talk about life in a regional town, their hopes for the future and issues that affect them and their world.
The end result is a portrait of young rural Victorians who are thoughtful and engaging, with concerns about the environment, world politics and the survival of small towns.
